questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. The pressure-volume diagram of her left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are seen in McArdle's disease. This patient has muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency.

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Image: Vacuolar myopathy in McArdle's disease

Features:

  • Poor exercise tolerance
  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

(B) - McArdle's disease

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The above image points show lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm which are characteristics of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

 Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

ALL is more common in childhood. The child had symptoms related to depression of marrow function including pallor, weight loss due to anemia and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
A patient who has had exposure to HBV will have Anti HBc antibodies even when he has moved into the chronic or recurrent stages. IgM anti-HBc reappears during acute recurrences while IgG Anti HBc is found in chronic states.

questions.text: A child on beta 2 agonists for the treatment of bronchial asthma may exhibit all of the following except:
questions.solution:
β2 agonists are associated with hyperglycemia probably due to β2 receptor-mediated glycogenolysis and glucagon release.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists are

  • Muscle tremors: Direct effect on beta 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Tachycardia: Direct effect on cardiac beta 2 receptors, indirect sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on beta 2 receptors
  • Hypokalemia: Direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions
  • Hypoxemia
  • Hyperglycaemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Tolerance: Desensitization on long-term use

questions.text: Late signs of death are all except:
questions.solution:
Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death whereas suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman Miller sign or Antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here the tumor grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in glomus tumor, when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - Antral sign or Holman Miller sign

questions.text: A 30-day-old infant is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
• From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color (if not, the inner square is a little darker than the outer circle) and thus cannot be used.
  • Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and KF rings are diagnostic in symptomatic cases of Wilson's disease.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice.

Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Dynamic testing for Cushing’s syndrome
  High dose dexamethasone suppression test CRH stimulation test
Pituitary adenoma Positive (suppressed cortisol) Positive (increase in ACTH and cortisol)
Ectopic ACTH Negative Negative
Iatrogenic: Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing
Adrenal mass or hyperplasia:  Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid. 

Option A: Exogenous steroid administration presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

Option B: Pituitary adenoma presents with elevated ACTH but a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is positive (suppressed).

Option C: Adrenal adenoma presents with suppressed ACTH levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of COVID-19?

choices.text: Reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction test

questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of Covid-19 is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR: This method involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA.

Rapid antigen test (RAT): Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

Antibody testing: Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumor penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma (in general):

TNM staging Treatment
T1a Simple cholecystectomy
T1b, T2, T3 Radical cholecystectomy
T4 Unresectable, chemotherapy and palliative nonsurgical therapy are provided
N1 Regional lymphadenectomy
N2 Radical cholecystectomy plus hepatopancreatic duodenectomy


If the carcinoma gall bladder was found incidentally after cholecystectomy:

  • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, standard cholecystectomy would suffice
  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

Chemotherapy is not required in early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma

TNM staging of gallbladder carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) guidelines, 8th edition:

TX: Main tumor cannot be assessed due to lack of information

T0: No sign of a primary tumor

Tis: Cancer is only in the epithelium (the inner layer of the gallbladder) and has not grown into deeper layers of the gallbladder.

T1: Tumor invades the lamina propria or the muscle layer (muscularis). 

  T1a:  Tumor invades the lamina propria

  T1b: Tumor invades the muscular layer

T2a: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the peritoneum (the lining of the abdominal cavity). 

T2b: Tumor invades the muscle layer into the fibrous tissue on the side of the liver, but has not invaded the liver.

T3: Tumor invades the serosa and/or it has grown directly into the liver and/or one nearby structure like the stomach, duodenum, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver.

T4: Tumor invades the main blood vessels leading into the liver (portal vein or hepatic artery) or it has grown into 2 or more structures outside the liver.

 

NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed due to lack of information.

N0: Not spread to nearby lymph nodes 

N1: Spread to < 3 nearby lymph nodes

N2: Spread to >4 nearby lymph nodes 

 

M0: Not spread to distant sites

questions.text: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following an episode of binge drinking. 7-days post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage.

A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected.

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Elevated white blood cell count
  • Abdominal pain

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection.

Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

questions.text: A 34 year old construction worker with no comorbidities presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco.

Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.
  • MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.
  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for 2 days at 12 weeks of gestation.  She also complains of excessive vomiting for one week. USG was done and it is given below.  What is the probable diagnosis____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of complete mole.  The USG image shows the characteristic “snowstorm” appearance seen in complete mole. Notably, a fetus and amnionic sac are absent. 

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Here post evacuation, Intrauterine devices are not recommended during the period of surveillance. This is because there is increased risk of perforation during this period if an invasive mole is present.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer.

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Thyroid pulmonary metastases (chest radiograph)

questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: “Social smile” is typically seen at ____ months and “stranger anxiety,” at ____ months.
questions.solution:
Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months.

Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age social smile develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else’s smile.

Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. The plain radiograph is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Complications:

  • Stiffness of joints: Finger stiffness is commonly seen
  • Malunion - can produce dinner-fork deformity
  • Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - Uncommon
  • Sudek's osteodystrophy - Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of this condition in the upper limb.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of ______.
questions.solution:
Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and is also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder.

The triad of symptoms seen is (GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia ( first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Treatment

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease. For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent inhaled anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The most potent inhaled anesthetic among the given options is halothane, with a minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of 0.75%.

The least potent inhaled anesthetic is nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%.

Note: Methoxyflurane has a MAC of 0.16%, making it more potent than halothane. However, it is obsolete now. The most potent agent overall is methoxyflurane and the most potent agent in clinical use is halothane.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: While collecting data on nail changes in psoriasis patients, you note the following findings. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch (image C), a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. The reddish-brown color is due to dilated, tortuous, superficial capillaries in the papillary dermis and parakeratosis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The patient's chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows left-sided pneumothorax with the partial collapse of the left lung. Best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of a pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).

questions.text: 4R’s of Radiotherapy are:
questions.solution:
In general, success or failure of standard clinical radiation treatment is determined by the 4 R’s of radiobiology: repair of DNA damage, redistribution of cells in the cell cycle, repopulation, and reoxygenation of hypoxic tumor areas.

5th R of radiotherapy is radiosensitivity.
